<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>If you recall, one of the first notes I ever wrote in this section was that my happiness this summer would be determined by how much quality ice cream I was able to eat. Well, I’m pleased to report that satisfaction levels are through the roof. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Yesterday, I visited the Tillamook Creamery on the Oregon coast, and it was as close to a Holy Temple for dairy as we’ve managed to build—oozing grilled cheese, generous ice cream portions, baseball team-like merchandise, all surrounded by the beautiful sights (and smells) of dairy farms. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It’s a good reminder that if you want the best of something...just go straight to the source.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>

</tr>

</tr>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">

<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
Q&A
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With...Malcolm Gladwell
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/09/icebreakers-withmalcolm-gladwell?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Malcolm Gladwell" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NzE2L21hbGNvbG1fZ2xhZHdlbGwuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Panoply</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Malcolm Gladwell is a journalist, author, and podcast host with something super brilliant to say on just about everything. So we peppered him with wide-ranging questions, focusing on topics from the newest season of his podcast, <a href="http://podcasts.pushkin.fm/mbicebreakers?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Revisionist History</em></a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>10 years down the line, which activity will passengers in driverless cars do most frequently: work, sleep, chat, or something else? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">All of the above! The biggest worry, of course, is that we’ll be able to use our time so productively while being driven around that we’ll drive everywhere, at the drop of the hat, and the world’s already terrible traffic will only get worse. I mean, right now you might take the train to work instead of braving rush-hour traffic. But if you can watch Netflix the whole time, why would you care about being stuck in traffic?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Should we trust the US News & World Report college rankings? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Of course not! OMG. Is that not obvious? Think back on your time in college and what you liked most about that experience. And then ask yourself: Is that thing you remember so well measurable and quantifiable? Or ask yourself: Is it possible (if we’re being honest about it) to compare, say, the Air Force Academy with Yeshiva University, using the same metrics and the same scale? I mean, come on.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>When did you realize </strong><strong><em>The Little Mermaid</em></strong><strong> was not like other Disney movies?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I read a brilliant law review essay about <em>The Little Mermaid</em> by a law professor in Chicago named Laura Beth Nielsen. And what I learned was so disturbing that I decided that I had to (very belatedly) watch the movie. Let me just say this: It was <em>much worse</em> than I had anticipated. That’s why we ended up doing three episodes on the movie in the new season of <em>Revisionist History</em>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Do you still believe in the 10,000-hour rule? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I believe what I have always believed, that true expertise in any cognitively complex field requires <em>a lot</em> of preparation. Far more than we imagine. Does that preparation always take 10,000 hours? Of course not. That number is more metaphor than prescription.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If you did not have to sleep, how would you spend the extra hours?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Sleep is literally my favorite thing to do. If I did not have to sleep, I would sleep anyway. I would fake it! I would lie in bed and pretend to be one of those lucky humans who needs to sleep.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What do you most often think about when you’re long-distance running?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When I finish a run I usually think only about food. I always run before dinner. It’s my version of an aperitif.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What would you write on a gigantic billboard?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">“I went on Morning Brew and all I got was this gigantic empty billboard :).” Seriously? I would repeat the greatest of all journalism dictums: “Afflict the comfortable! And comfort the afflicted!”<br><strong></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If you had to make your own zombie movie, what would your zombies be like? How would they be different from stereotypical zombies?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">My zombies would be Canadian, like me. They would be unfailingly polite. They would run a clean and functional zombie-universe. They would look upon their southern zombie neighbors with a certain degree of alarm. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>

<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Am I Ready to Become a Manager?
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/09/make-work-right-time-become-manager?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reader-submitted questions</a> about work in 2021. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I have been at my first job for two years and just received a promotion. Now, my boss wants to put me into a manager role. I don’t think I’m ready or qualified for the role. How do I deal with that?—Emily from Texas</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Congrats on your recent promotion! It’s totally normal for you to feel nervous about becoming a manager. It’s not like anyone says, “I want to be a manager when I grow up!”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The good news is, managing can be learned with enough work and patience. If you feel underqualified to become a manager, share your reservations with your supervisor. They might have felt the same way when stepping into their position. Together you can create a plan that will set you up for success in the role, with the understanding that no one is going to be perfect from Day 1.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Also, make sure that what you’re feeling isn't imposter syndrome. For your manager to see potential in your growth at the company means that they believe you are capable of doing the work. But only you can want it. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Of course, while managing can be extremely rewarding, it certainly isn’t for everyone. If you’ve reflected and decided that you have no desire to transition into a management position, then you should be transparent with your boss.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But...I think you should give it a shot! Schedule a three-month trial run (at the manager's rate of pay, of course) so there’s no pressure on you to continue if you absolutely hate it. Let us know what happens!</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Something bothering you at work? </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Ask Kate here</em></a><em>.</em></p>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
The Daredevil Executive
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/09/branson-space-risky-reckless?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Virgin" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82NjIvcmljaGFyZF9icmFuc29uLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Virgin Galactic</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When Richard Branson blasts off to space today, he’ll be putting himself in more danger than if he had walked to the local brunch spot for a Bloody Mary and an eggs benny. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The space plane he’s traveling in will reach <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/07/tech/richard-branson-space-flight-risk-scn/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">2,400 miles per hour</a> before it becomes suspended in microgravity more than 50 miles above Earth, after which it’ll do a somersault and trek back to solid ground. Virgin Galactic has completed more than 20 test flights, but the mission has been delayed by technical issues and a pilot died in a test flight in 2014.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">All of this to say, Branson is engaging in abnormally risky behavior. Should the company care? </p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">History as a guide</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Branson isn’t the first executive with a daredevil mentality. In 2012, the chief executive of memory chip maker Micron Technology, Steve Appleton, <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/insurance-ceo-risk/daredevil-ceos-may-put-their-companies-at-risk-idUSL2E8D6HDM20120207?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">died</a> when the experimental, self-assembled plane he was piloting crashed.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Appleton’s death <a href="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/are-daredevil-ceos-worth-risk-micron-thought-so-2012-02-07?adobe_mc=MCMID%3D16834921328861096140770344942750382964%7CMCORGID%3DCB68E4BA55144CAA0A4C98A5%2540AdobeOrg%7CTS%3D1625837144" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised questions</a> about whether the company’s board had any responsibility to be the uncool dad and say, “You know, Steve, you <em>are</em> running an $8 billion company with more than 26,000 employees...for our shareholders’ sake we can’t let you fly stunt planes anymore.” Or, at the very least publish disclosures around Appleton’s dangerous hobbies. </p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>Micron shares fell more than 6% following the news of Appleton’s death. At the time, it was also rumored to be in active talks to acquire a Japanese rival. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Some public companies have “key person” insurance policies to mitigate the financial fallout from the unexpected death of an executive, but most firms just assume <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/skydiving-mountain-climbing-and-other-ways-execs-terrify-their-shareholders-11561109403?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">it will never happen</a>, even if their leader races yachts like Oracle’s Larry Ellison or runs with the bulls like American Airlines CEO Doug Parker. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In fact, some experts think being a daredevil outside of work means you’re more likely to take risks during work, increasing your company’s odds of beating out competitors. A 2011 study found that CEOs with licenses to pilot small aircraft (an activity 30x more dangerous than driving a car) are 40% more likely to make a corporate acquisition and 15% more likely to take on greater leverage.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line: </strong>When Richard Branson decided to create a space company, it’s probably because he <em>wanted </em>to go to space. His personal ambitions are intertwined with the company’s—today's flight was inevitable. </p>

<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Open House
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that doesn’t pretend a cheap rug and a lime green Target chair make a home a mid-century modern showpiece. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/qIuuKH7OFJbNIHfQY3/giphy.gif" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="3,020 sqft mid century modern home in Saint Paul, Minnesota" data-source="Zillow" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Zillow</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This <a href="https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/1690-Bohland-Ave-Saint-Paul-MN-55116/2090007_zpid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">carpet haven</a> in Saint Paul, Minnesota, is going to be divisive. It was built in 1950, so you can only imagine the types of parties that were thrown behind its floor-to-ceiling windows. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>3,020 square feet, 4 beds, 3 baths</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Wallpaper that makes the room seem dirtier than it is</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Extremely charming light fixtures</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>A 20-minute walk to the golf course</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to live your postwar dream? Scroll to the bottom of the newsletter to find out.</p>

#353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eIf you recall, one of the first notes I ever wrote in this section was that my happiness this summer would be determined by how much quality ice cream I was able to eat. Well, I’m pleased to report that satisfaction levels are through the roof. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYesterday, I visited the Tillamook Creamery on the Oregon coast, and it was as close to a Holy Temple for dairy as we’ve managed to build—oozing grilled cheese, generous ice cream portions, baseball team-like merchandise, all surrounded by the beautiful sights (and smells) of dairy farms. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt’s a good reminder that if you want the best of something...just go straight to the source.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Malcolm Gladwell\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NzE2L21hbGNvbG1fZ2xhZHdlbGwuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003ePanoply\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMalcolm Gladwell is a journalist, author, and podcast host with something super brilliant to say on just about everything. So we peppered him with wide-ranging questions, focusing on topics from the newest season of his podcast, \u003ca href=\"http://podcasts.pushkin.fm/mbicebreakers?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eRevisionist History\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e10 years down the line, which activity will passengers in driverless cars do most frequently: work, sleep, chat, or something else? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAll of the above! The biggest worry, of course, is that we’ll be able to use our time so productively while being driven around that we’ll drive everywhere, at the drop of the hat, and the world’s already terrible traffic will only get worse. I mean, right now you might take the train to work instead of braving rush-hour traffic. But if you can watch Netflix the whole time, why would you care about being stuck in traffic?\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eShould we trust the US News \u0026 World Report college rankings? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOf course not! OMG. Is that not obvious? Think back on your time in college and what you liked most about that experience. And then ask yourself: Is that thing you remember so well measurable and quantifiable? Or ask yourself: Is it possible (if we’re being honest about it) to compare, say, the Air Force Academy with Yeshiva University, using the same metrics and the same scale? I mean, come on.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen did you realize \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Little Mermaid\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e was not like other Disney movies?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI read a brilliant law review essay about \u003cem\u003eThe Little Mermaid\u003c/em\u003e by a law professor in Chicago named Laura Beth Nielsen. And what I learned was so disturbing that I decided that I had to (very belatedly) watch the movie. Let me just say this: It was \u003cem\u003emuch worse\u003c/em\u003e than I had anticipated. That’s why we ended up doing three episodes on the movie in the new season of \u003cem\u003eRevisionist History\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDo you still believe in the 10,000-hour rule? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI believe what I have always believed, that true expertise in any cognitively complex field requires \u003cem\u003ea lot\u003c/em\u003e of preparation. Far more than we imagine. Does that preparation always take 10,000 hours? Of course not. That number is more metaphor than prescription.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you did not have to sleep, how would you spend the extra hours?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSleep is literally my favorite thing to do. If I did not have to sleep, I would sleep anyway. I would fake it! I would lie in bed and pretend to be one of those lucky humans who needs to sleep.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat do you most often think about when you’re long-distance running?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen I finish a run I usually think only about food. I always run before dinner. It’s my version of an aperitif.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat would you write on a gigantic billboard?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e“I went on Morning Brew and all I got was this gigantic empty billboard :).” Seriously? I would repeat the greatest of all journalism dictums: “Afflict the comfortable! And comfort the afflicted!”\u003cbr\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you had to make your own zombie movie, what would your zombies be like? How would they be different from stereotypical zombies?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMy zombies would be Canadian, like me. They would be unfailingly polite. They would run a clean and functional zombie-universe. They would look upon their southern zombie neighbors with a certain degree of alarm. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F09%2Ficebreakers-withmalcolm-gladwell\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make It Work logo\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereader-submitted questions\u003c/a\u003e about work in 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI have been at my first job for two years and just received a promotion. Now, my boss wants to put me into a manager role. I don’t think I’m ready or qualified for the role. How do I deal with that?—Emily from Texas\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eCongrats on your recent promotion! It’s totally normal for you to feel nervous about becoming a manager. It’s not like anyone says, “I want to be a manager when I grow up!”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe good news is, managing can be learned with enough work and patience. If you feel underqualified to become a manager, share your reservations with your supervisor. They might have felt the same way when stepping into their position. Together you can create a plan that will set you up for success in the role, with the understanding that no one is going to be perfect from Day 1.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAlso, make sure that what you’re feeling isn't imposter syndrome. For your manager to see potential in your growth at the company means that they believe you are capable of doing the work. But only you can want it. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOf course, while managing can be extremely rewarding, it certainly isn’t for everyone. If you’ve reflected and decided that you have no desire to transition into a management position, then you should be transparent with your boss.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut...I think you should give it a shot! Schedule a three-month trial run (at the manager's rate of pay, of course) so there’s no pressure on you to continue if you absolutely hate it. Let us know what happens!\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSomething bothering you at work? \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAsk Kate here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F09%2Fmake-work-right-time-become-manager\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nThe Daredevil Executive\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/09/branson-space-risky-reckless?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Virgin\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82NjIvcmljaGFyZF9icmFuc29uLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eVirgin Galactic\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen Richard Branson blasts off to space today, he’ll be putting himself in more danger than if he had walked to the local brunch spot for a Bloody Mary and an eggs benny. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe space plane he’s traveling in will reach \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/07/tech/richard-branson-space-flight-risk-scn/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e2,400 miles per hour\u003c/a\u003e before it becomes suspended in microgravity more than 50 miles above Earth, after which it’ll do a somersault and trek back to solid ground. Virgin Galactic has completed more than 20 test flights, but the mission has been delayed by technical issues and a pilot died in a test flight in 2014.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAll of this to say, Branson is engaging in abnormally risky behavior. Should the company care? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eHistory as a guide\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBranson isn’t the first executive with a daredevil mentality. In 2012, the chief executive of memory chip maker Micron Technology, Steve Appleton, \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/insurance-ceo-risk/daredevil-ceos-may-put-their-companies-at-risk-idUSL2E8D6HDM20120207?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edied\u003c/a\u003e when the experimental, self-assembled plane he was piloting crashed.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAppleton’s death \u003ca href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/are-daredevil-ceos-worth-risk-micron-thought-so-2012-02-07?adobe_mc=MCMID%3D16834921328861096140770344942750382964%7CMCORGID%3DCB68E4BA55144CAA0A4C98A5%2540AdobeOrg%7CTS%3D1625837144\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised questions\u003c/a\u003e about whether the company’s board had any responsibility to be the uncool dad and say, “You know, Steve, you \u003cem\u003eare\u003c/em\u003e running an $8 billion company with more than 26,000 employees...for our shareholders’ sake we can’t let you fly stunt planes anymore.” Or, at the very least publish disclosures around Appleton’s dangerous hobbies. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMicron shares fell more than 6% following the news of Appleton’s death. At the time, it was also rumored to be in active talks to acquire a Japanese rival. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSome public companies have “key person” insurance policies to mitigate the financial fallout from the unexpected death of an executive, but most firms just assume \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/skydiving-mountain-climbing-and-other-ways-execs-terrify-their-shareholders-11561109403?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eit will never happen\u003c/a\u003e, even if their leader races yachts like Oracle’s Larry Ellison or runs with the bulls like American Airlines CEO Doug Parker. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn fact, some experts think being a daredevil outside of work means you’re more likely to take risks during work, increasing your company’s odds of beating out competitors. A 2011 study found that CEOs with licenses to pilot small aircraft (an activity 30x more dangerous than driving a car) are 40% more likely to make a corporate acquisition and 15% more likely to take on greater leverage.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eWhen Richard Branson decided to create a space company, it’s probably because he \u003cem\u003ewanted \u003c/em\u003eto go to space. His personal ambitions are intertwined with the company’s—today's flight was inevitable. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F09%2Fbranson-space-risky-reckless\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
